Award.AwardTitle: US-Egypt Cooperative Research: Managing Grid Integration of Large-Scale Wind Power Parks using Energy Storage Technology and Demand Response
Award.AbstractNarration:
1104023
This project supports a cooperative research project by Dr. Saifur Rahman at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (VA Tech) and Dr. Mohamed El-Sobki, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt. They plan to study the management of grid integration of large scale wind power parks. As large wind power parks, or wind farms, rapidly expand around the world, electric power systems operators face new challenges. While it is desirable to use the zero-emission wind energy, managing large wind parks integration is difficult due to the intermittency and fluctuation of their power production. Therefore, it is of the interest of the United States, Egypt, and other countries with wind generation to seek solutions for integration of large wind farms without compromising their power grid stability and reliability. This research involves using an energy storage technology and demand response techniques for managing the grid integration of large wind parks. Specifically, it aims to develop novel sizing, scheduling and control methods to enable an application based on compressed-air energy storage (CAES) technology for partial smoothing of the high-rate fluctuations of multiple wind parks output. Furthermore, it develops a new operation scheme for combining the load regulation capability of demand response techniques with the energy storage to increase wind power utilization and thereby reduce wind curtailment. The application is also designed with added functions to provide real and reactive power support for stabilizing the power grid and coping with grid emergency situations.

Intellectual Merit:
The PIs will develop novel sizing, scheduling and control methods for compressed-air energy storage technology (CAES), which are applied to wind power integration applications at utility scale. It will also develop a new operation scheme for combining the load regulation capability of demand response techniques with CAES. The research outcome will contribute a set of analytical tools, which are needed for managing the integration of large-scale wind power parks into power systems while ensuring the safe operation of the power grids.

Broader Impacts: The research outcome will fill in the need for high-efficiency solutions to manage wind power on a large scale. The resulted application based on CAES technology and demand response will improve the integration and conservation of wind energy, which benefit both electric utilities and wind developers. Increased wind energy integration helps utilities meet their renewable mandates and enhances revenues for wind investors. This international collaborative project creates a valuable opportunity for U.S.
researchers and students to work with Egyptian researchers on the technical problems for mutual benefit.
Overall, the joint research contributes innovative tools to ensure safe operation of power grids, increase wind energy usage thereby reducing carbon emissions and helping protect the environment. These factors foster the sustainable economic development of Egypt and the United States. The US team includes two women scientists at Virginia Tech, Dr. Ha Thu Le, a postdoctoral researcher and Dr. Manisa Pipattanasomporn, a junior scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High wind penetration is a potential future scenario resulting from many energy and environmental policies. U.S. annual wind generation in 2012 was 3.5%. The installed wind capacity in Egypt by the end of 2014 was 610 MW. Siemens was awarded for building 2 GW of wind power generation capacity in Egypt. This proves the importance of analyzing high wind energy penetration challenges and proposing solutions for mitigating them.

This joint research between Virginia Tech (USA) and Cairo University (EGYPT) explored the application of energy storage and demand response techniques for managing grid integration of large wind parks. Specifically, it aimed at developing novel sizing, scheduling and control methods to enable the use of compressed-air energy storage (CAES) technology and Sodium Sulfur (NaS) battery. Demand response is studied with integrated energy storage to increase wind power utilization and thereby reduce wind curtailment.

In high wind energy penetration scenarios, there are cases where load minus wind power is less than must-run generation (e.g., large nuclear power plants). This excess of wind energy needs to be spilled to keep the balance between load and generation. Wind forecast error is another challenge in high wind energy penetration scenarios that increases wind spillage and required back-up energy. Energy storage and demand response are solutions to mitigate these challenges.

The outcome of this research is detailed modeling of energy storage technologies and demand response. Two different grid-scale energy storage technologies are used in this research. CAES is a mechanical grid-scale energy storage that has its own characteristics like minimum required idle time to switch between charge and discharge modes. The other one is NaS battery which is chemical energy storage and has prompt response (full power charge to discharge in milliseconds). Demand response (DR) is another flexible resource in the system that can mitigate high wind energy penetration scenarios. The rebound effect occurring after DR is a phenomena associated with DR which is modeled in this research.

The other outcome of this research is proposing an algorithm based on signal processing methods to decompose the wind power forecast error signal to time-varying periodic components. This is based on the concept that the efficient operation of energy storage or conventional units depends on their cycling. The wind forecast error signal is decomposed to intra-hour, intra-day and slow-cycling components to control NaS, CAES, and conventional units, respectively. The slow-cycling component is followed by conventional generators which are more efficient to operate close to rated capacity. The trade-off between installing more energy storage units and decreasing the wind spillage, and back-up energy is analyzed.

Proposed models and algorithms are applicable using real world wind and load data. Since short term wind data was not available from Egypt, US wind farm data obtained from the Bonneville Power Administration in 2013 was used. When researchers have access to Egypt wind data, they can use the same model presented in this report to carry out an in-country analysis. Egypt has not deployed grid-scale energy storage technologies including CAES and NaS battery yet, but these technologies can be good options for them to consider.

Products of the award are two seminars presented by Prof. Saifur Rahman at Cairo University, and also a conference paper, and a poster presented at IEEE PES GM conferences, and one published journal paper at IEEE Transaction on Sustainable Energy.
